There is a hidden layer. Let me explain how it is set up. The system 
was u=
sed like a host to implement HyperNEAT. I haven't another 
involving many i=
nputs to properly test it with. 
3 possible substrate configurations are cu=
rrently supported- 
parralel, circular and random. Parralel is arrangement =
of nodes in 
layers, in the circular case, there are 3 rings of nodes, the =
outer 
one is the input layer, the middle one are the hidden neurons and th=
e 
inner are the outputs. The rings reside on radiuses 0.99, 0.66 and 
0.33=
 from the origin. This looks very.. cool when viewed with all 
connections =
:) 
It was easy to turn regular NEAT into HyperNEAT. 
Instead of giving the=
 roving eye a brain directly created from a NEAT 
genome, I give it a big n=
etwork created from a temporary genome and 
the newtork that used to be its=
 brain is now used as a CPPN. 
And this is it. Everything else is untouched=
 from the original 
version. 
I wrote some nice looking GUI too.. I'll uplo=
ad it soon so you can 
check it out.. 


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenn=
eth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Really you have a roving eye vision =
system already working with 
> HyperNEAT?  How is it set up?  Is there a hi=
dden layer?
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
=
> <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> >
> > >
> > > Wow Peter, that is fast work!
=
> > > 
> > 
> > Yeah, it was about a day of coding :) I even applied it to =
the 
> Active 
> > Vision system from ANJI (my own implementation of it).. =
current 
> > results show that with HyperNEAT it learns actually better, an=
d 
> the 
> > circular substrate configuration increases performance among =

> > others. :)
> > 
> > > Assigning node-centric values is a legitimate re=
search 
problem.  
> > The 
> > > simplest answer is that a CPPN can have m=
ore than a single 
> output.  
> > > There can be additional outputs for th=
ings like biases and 
> learning 
> > > rates.  Each such property will the=
n be patterned across the 
> > substrate 
> > > just like weights.
> > > 
>=
 > > However, the one problem that comes up with nodes is that node-
> > ce=
ntric 
> > > properties are overspecified by a 4D CPPN because nodes are 
>=
 > specified 
> > > by only two dimensions (that is, they are points in spa=
ce 
rather 
> > than 
> > > lines).  Therefore, you have to set a conventio=
n for when to 
> read 
> > the 
> > > value of a node-centric output and as=
sign it to a node.  For 
> > example, 
> > > you could say that the node at=
 x1 y1 is set to the value of the 
> > node 
> > > output only when x2 y2 a=
re both zero.  Of course there are many 
> > > alternative ways it could be=
 done, but some convention must be 
> > set.  
> > 
> > I will try to do th=
e following.. the CPPN will have 2 more 
> outputs, 
> > that will specity =
the time constant and bias of THE SECOND node, 
> > (x2,y2) .. I think this=
 shouldn't hurt performance.. But I guess 
> it 
> > will take some trial a=
nd error. 
> > 
> > Peter
> >
>
